solution.sample:
The initial values of weights are usually random or taken from a neural network solving a related task.
 
During training, weights are modified to try to minimize the value of an error function (called also loss function), which describes how far actual outputs are from the desired outputs. Training algorithms (also called learning algorithms) repeatedly compute small corrections (called updates) to weights until the error function is minimum or small enough for all examples in the training set, or until a desired performance is observed in a different held-out development set.
 
Updating is usually based on computing how much the error function varies when each weight is varied by a fixed but very small amount and then varying each weight a little, precisely in the direction in which it reduces the error function.
